title: 104_s598
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the selling price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. For cigarettes, the tax rate is raised to $62 per thousand. The tax rates on various tobacco products are being increased as part of the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995". The tax on cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, snuff, and chewing tobacco is being raised significantly. For example, the tax on cigarette papers is increased from 0.75 cents to 3.875 cents. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are being increased significantly. For example, the tax on smokeless tobacco is raised from 36 cents to $1.86. The amendments will apply to tobacco products removed after December 31, 1995. Additionally, an excise tax will be imposed on the manufacture or importation of roll-your-own tobacco. An excise tax of $1.86 per pound will be imposed on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. Roll-your-own tobacco is defined as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Technical amendments are also made to the tax code. The tax code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax, defined as tobacco for making cigarettes. Amendments also cover cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco for personal consumption. The tax code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax, covering cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco for personal consumption. Chapter 52 on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes is revised in the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. The tax code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax, covering cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco for personal consumption. Chapter 52 on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes is revised in the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. The effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 1995, with a transitional rule allowing certain individuals to continue engaging in the tobacco business pending final action on their application. The tax code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax, covering cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco for personal consumption. Applicants under subchapter B of chapter 52 can continue engaging in the tobacco business pending final action on their application. Floor stocks taxes are imposed on certain tobacco products held for sale before January 1, 1996. Taxes are imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes, and cigarette papers based on weight and price. Taxes are imposed on cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, snuff, and chewing tobacco based on specific measurements and weight. Taxes are imposed on various tobacco products based on weight and measurements, with specific rates for snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Liability for the tax falls on individuals holding these products on January 1, 1996, with payment due by February 15, 1996. The tax on tobacco products is due on February 15, 1996, following the same payment method as other tobacco taxes. The terms for different tobacco products are defined in the Internal Revenue Code. Retail stocks are exempt from these taxes. The tax on tobacco products is due on February 15, 1996, as per the Internal Revenue Code. Retail stocks of certain tobacco products are exempt from these taxes. Foreign trade zones have specific provisions regarding the taxation of cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products. Tobacco products subject to tax under specific provisions of the Act of June 18, 1934, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, are subject to taxation. This includes cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco placed under customs supervision before January 1, 1996. Tobacco products imported into the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, are subject to taxation. This includes cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for this purpose. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund was established under the Internal Revenue Code for taxing tobacco products imported into the US from foreign trade zones after January 1, 1996. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, established in the Treasury, receives 3 percent of revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments for assisting farmers in transitioning to other crops and providing grants to communities and individuals. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund assists farmers in transitioning from tobacco to other crops and provides grants to support economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. This includes government purchase of tobacco allotments to retire them from farmers choosing to exit tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund supports farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops and provides grants for economic diversification in communities and individuals involved in tobacco production.
